article.title: The Extended IRTF Spectral Library: Expanded coverage in metallicity, temperature, and surface gravity

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the different panels (a-e) in Figure 1?
choices: To show the evolution of stellar parameters with time for different metallicity bins.
To demonstrate the spectral coverage of different telescopes for various stellar types.
To compare the stellar parameter coverage of the MILES spectral library with the new IRTF library.
To illustrate the impact of atmospheric absorption on observed stellar spectra.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the red line in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The atmospheric transmission spectrum at Maunakea.
The spectrum of BD+053080 before telluric correction.
The spectrum of BD+053080 after telluric correction and flux calibration.
A theoretical spectrum of an A0V star.

multiple_choice_question.text: What issue does Figure 3 highlight about the telluric correction process?
choices: The atmospheric transmission model does not accurately represent the true atmospheric conditions.
The A0V standard stars used for telluric correction have prominent hydrogen and metal lines, introducing spurious features.
The SpeX instrument resolution is too low to accurately correct for telluric absorption.
The spectral extraction process introduces unphysical features in the telluric spectrum.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from Figure 4 regarding the empirical uncertainty of the IRTF library spectra?
choices: The empirical uncertainty is generally less than 1% except in regions affected by telluric absorption or prominent A0V standard star features.
The empirical uncertainty is dominated by statistical (photon-counting) noise.
The empirical uncertainty is consistent with the Poisson uncertainty throughout the wavelength range.
The empirical uncertainty is significantly higher in the J band compared to other bands.
